* Percutaneous or surgical pericardial drainage:
** indicated urgently in the event of tamponade or to be discussed in the event of haemodynamic repercussions on echo with blood pressure preserved :
** sometimes also indicated in cases of chronic abundant effusion with no obvious aetiology
** percutaneous or pericardiocentesis, preferable if the patient is unstable, using an ultrasound-guided needle puncture under the sternum
** surgical, to be preferred if purulent effusion is suspected (a larger bore drain can be used)
** In all cases, ''analysis of drained fluid'': bacteriological, virological, cytological >>> contributes to the aetiological assessment.

question.title: When to perform pericardial drainage
question.description: In the context of acute pericarditis, when is pericardial drainage indicated?

option_a.title: Only in cases of tamponade or haemodynamic repercussions
option_a.description: In cases of tamponade or haemodynamic repercussions, pericardial drainage is indicated

option_b.title: Always in cases of chronic abundant effusion
option_b.description: In cases of chronic abundant effusion, pericardial drainage is always indicated

option_c.title: When the patient is unstable and has a large effusion
option_c.description: When the patient is unstable and has a large effusion, pericardial drainage is indicated

option_d.title: To analyze the drained fluid for infection
option_d.description: The primary purpose of pericardial drainage is to analyze the drained fluid for infection
